newsitem.title: FRANCE: France sets trucker hours, angers one union.
newsitem.headline: France sets trucker hours, angers one union.

text.p: The French cabinet on Wednesday approved a draft decree on working hours for truckers after a 12-day strike last month, but one major union slammed the scheme and urged drivers to make new, unspecified, protests.

The draft decree, seeking to settle truckers' key claims for pay for compulsory rest breaks and waiting for loading, set a ceiling from January 1 of up to a quarter of the working day for such paid pauses and below three hours daily.

But the transport branch of the Force Ouvriere union, France's third biggest, said the decree was "a real step backwards" that would allow road haulage companies to wriggle out of extra payments. It called on truckers to examine the situation and immediately take steps to show "they have had enough," it said in a statement.

It stopped short of calling for specific protests. Extra pay and a better definition of working hours were major triggers of last month's strikes, along with an agreed demand for retirement at age 55.
The government, which had called on the truckers and road haulage companies to work out a deal over working hours, had said it would rule by decree if they failed.
